data.title: Investing in S&P 500 Companies: Key Considerations
meta_keywords: should i invest in s&p 500 now
data.meta_description: The S&P 500 has generally historically delivered returns through volatile markets. Read why investors should consider investing in this group of companies.
data.text:
Over time, this index of major U.S. companies has proven remarkably resilient. âEven during the global pandemic, rising geopolitical tensions, natural disasters and the war in Ukraine, U.S. equities represented by the S&P 500 Index are higher by 233% on a total return basis over the last 10 years,â1 says Marci McGregor, head of CIO Portfolio Strategy in the Chief Investment Office, Merrill and Bank of America Private Bank. While past performance doesnât guarantee future results, âThe returns of the companies on this index over this period of time are impressive from a historical perspective,â notes Kirsten Cabacungan, an investment strategist in the CIO for Merrill and Bank of America Private Bank.

A selective list

Though numerically just a small portion of the more than 3,500 publicly listed companies based in the United States,2 S&P 500 companies represent about 80% of total U.S. market capitalization. Thus the index, created in 1957, is widely regarded as a âproxyâ for the broader U.S. equity market.3

To be selected for inclusion in this index, companies must have at least $15.78 billion in market capitalization (as of March 28, 2024), have positive earnings in the most recent quarter and year and meet a host of other standards.3 TheÂ list is continually updated by the S&Pâs U.S. Index Committee as companies expand or decline, and this regular refresh may help to explain the indexâs historical resilience in the face of market pressures.

A benchmark for quality, yield, real returns and more

McGregor and Cabacungan point to some additional underlying qualities that make the S&P 500 such an important benchmark and share some points for investors to consider.

They include:

Quality. S&P 500 companies are often considered most representative of the key industries in the economy, and they tend to be large-cap stocks with relatively higher quality and stable businesses.

Yield.Â Many companies in the S&P 500 pay dividends to shareholders that can offer an alternative form of income in addition to any income investors receive from their bond holdings. âThis can also provide an added form of diversification,â McGregor notes.

Access to secular growth. The U.S. is a global innovation juggernaut and home to world-leading technology firms, many of which are listed on the S&P 500. But innovation and efficiencies arenât limited to tech companies or the tech sector. Many businesses listed on the S&P 500 now harness the power of technology and automation and are found across all sectors.

Real returns. While inflation affects individual companies and industries differently, the S&P 500 over the long term has historically provided positive real returns â or the amount earned after accounting for taxes and inflation â as companies have become more productive and able to pass higher costs on to consumers.4 âEven during the Great Inflation decade from 1971 to 1980, consumer prices rose by a cumulative 117%, but the S&P 500âs total return was higher at 125%,â5 notes McGregor.

A foundation for consistent earnings.Â Because of the stringent requirements for inclusion in the S&P 500, the companies listed in the index tend to be those that have generally kept up with long-term structural changes in the economy, technology and consumer preferences, which typically contributes to a rise in corporate earningsÂ â the foundation for long-term equity gains.

Durability during and after recessions.Â Considering the last four recessions, the S&P 500 tended to perform better on average in terms of price return, both during and 12 months after the start of the recession, compared with global peers and commodities.5

Ongoing reinvention. âCreative destruction, or the process of constant reinvention as emerging companies become eligible for inclusion and others drop off, has transformed the S&P 500 over time,â Cabacungan says6. In 1969, industrials represented a third of the index. Todayâs leadership composition of the S&P 500 differs substantially from decades prior. In 1990, there was a more varied mix of sector leaders â across Energy, Industrials, Healthcare, and a few Technology names. Today, the latter sector dominates. Company size has skewed so large that, in fact, the top five largest stocks in the S&P 500 are each of greater value than the entire Technology sector in 1990.7.

What the S&P 500 might mean for you

If you own individual large-cap stocks, you may likely be invested in one or more companiesÂ listed on the index. Many index-based mutual funds and exchange-traded funds invest with the intent of tracking or mimicking the S&Pâs yearly performance and own all 500 of the indexâs stocks. And because it has such broad exposure across sectors, the index is a useful benchmark, offering insights on the overall strength of the markets and the economy.

A reminder: S&P 500 companies donât guarantee results, Hyzy cautions. All investments carry risk and are subject to challenging conditions, including periods of heightened market volatility, such as what we saw in 2022, he notes. Nor should investors focus solely on the S&P 500. Stocks of smaller, promising companies and international equities can offer important potential growth opportunities for investors, while bonds and other assets are essential for diversification.

Bottom line: While there will always be volatility and results may vary from year to year, McGregor believes S&P 500 companies will continue to offer important benefits for investors. âGiven their improving productivity, proven durability, higher quality and consistency of earnings growth, we believe this group of companies should be considered as a core holding for long-term investors.â
